author: @MangoHombre
text:
This film made me think of the Jimmy Buffett song "It's My Job":
In the middle of late last night I was sittin' on a curb
I didn't know what about but I was feeling quite disturbed
A street sweeper came whistlin' by
He was bouncin' every step
It seemed strange how good he felt
So I asked him while he swept
He said "It's my job to be cleaning up this mess
And that's enough reason to go for me
It's my job to be better than the rest
And that makes the day for me"

author: @fdl238
text: Who knew watching a toilet cleaner's everyday life would be therapeutic. It was like being there, enjoying the simple things in life like eating at the park. I watched this at home and it gave me that "cozy" feeling. Plus, those public facilities are a work of art! We don't have those in our country as far as I know. My favorite is the one that turns opaque and transparent.

text:
The scene with his sister was SO well written and acted.... With the minimum of lines and the incredible facial expressions, we could understand what he had escaped from, what he was never returning to, why he and his sister were different, what the relationship with his father was, how his sister perceived him (with a complex mixture of envy, disdain, sorrow, regret, and more...).
Just amazing.

text:
Really wonderful film. Just felt like a really big long hug.

The only way i could describe it is that (to reference another iconic Japanese film) its like My Neighbour Totoro in that theres no huge story arc, no sudden Hollywood attack of space monkeys with guns, just a man and his life, portrayed beautifully. And although its 2hr 4 mins. It doesnt drag at all.

author: @samroome
text: Great to watch with this film: Jim Jarmusch's "Paterson" starring Adam Driver as a bus driver and unpublished poet in Paterson (yes, William Carlos Williams!) NJ. Wenders gave Jarmusch leftover film stock to make his 30-minute short version of "Stranger Than Paradise." They've come full circle.

 Como es un film casi  sin argumento ,eso mismo resalta la forma ,sumamente bella ,en que estÃ¡ contada la historia.
  y hacia que mi atenciÃ³n se concentrara en las distintas acciones del protagonista y estÃ¡ concentraciÃ³n era tal que me ayudaba a anular el futuro y el pasado.Cuando salÃ­ del cine el viento arrastraba unas hojas y yo me di cuenta que aÃºn no habÃ­a salido de la pelÃ­cula...

author: @stevepang378
text: In this movie, it's the first time I heard of Patricia Highsmith who once toasted, "To all the devils, lusts, passions, greeds, envies, loves, hates, strange desires, enemies ghostly and real, the army of memories, with which I do battleâ€”may they never give me peace". Wim Wenders intended in this movie to kill all those and created a slow pace, at peace with yourself in the humblest things you do and see heart in simple music, plants and extremely simple human nature. Distilled to the simplest, at peace and enjoy most of your humble self; we all understand the toilet more than we think and our need of it. To get it all out, slow or fast or take your time.

author: @LXKeemProductions
text: His days were indeed perfect, colors, music, work, sauna, photography and cassette tapes brought extra joy to this daily routine. This is another great example of celebration of life in Japan, a country with one of the highest qualities of life in the world and yet many sadnesses and stresses created by people's thoughful minds. "Drive my car" and "Broker" are another amazing celebrations of life in Japanese cinema, with "Broker" being a South Korean film written, edited and directed by Japanese filmmaker.

author: @clarus_tx
text: A very great film coming out of Japan. Perfect Days shows us a view of life into the underappreciated in our society. It's a story of finding happiness despite our roles in life, and about the day-to-day connections we have.

text:
The film boldly sets the tone with its title, "Perfect Days," paying homage to Lou Reed's song. This literal announcement initially lowered my expectations, fearing a contemplative stroll without any substance. The song "Perfect Day" almost too obviously underscores the film's philosophy and its character, Hirayama-san. Right from the beginning, the film confirmed this impression as the cinematography is meticulously aligned with the daily routine of the custodian portrayed. However, despite the playlist's lack of originality ("House of the Rising Sun", "Feeling Good"...), the film's magic eventually prevails. The production originates from a government initiative to promote Tokyo's "artistic" designed toilets to the world who couldnâ€™t join the Olympics due to COVID-19. Wim Wenders uses that initial ambition to honor something else to be honored about Japan: its cleanliness culture and virtues. Virtue in patience. Virtue in environmental protection. Virtue in curiosity (whether literary or musical). Virtue in the server-served relationship (whether at the bar or in restrooms). Virtue in respect of a strangerâ€™s intimacy (whether itâ€™s at the public bath or anywhere for that matter). All carefully presented without any irony. Indeed, through Yakusho Koji's tender portrayal, Wim Wenders declares his very own profound and sincere love for Japan. 

There's a saying: "Not all heroes wear capes". And Hirayama-san falls in that category. Instead, he actually wears his public toilet uniform. Despite flaws, Wenders doesn't seek absolute redemption for Hirayama-san, presenting him as a hero with imperfections. Like Sam Raimiâ€™s Spiderman or Martin Campbellâ€™s Zorro, these heroes remain human, relatable figures. Hirayama-san has flaws, but the film refrains from being judgmental about his lifestyle. This discretion in the directing is particularly showcased in the absence of editing when, for instance, Hirayama-san ignores (or at least does not reply to) the bookseller's comments. A typical Japanese trait, that is introversion towards strangers, which could be perceived as negative to the western eye. Instead, we just follow along the old man's adventure (or lack of adventure) until he gets offered a choice: Continue living by stretching time, savoring "perfect days" in solitude... or embrace a romantic adventure, reunite with his family, and make new friendships like the ones that brings you to drink beers along the Sumida River... So far, Hirayama-san was choosing the former. It's a choice that belongs to each of us. Here it is perfectly encapsulated by the film's beauty and cruelty, echoing life's mantra: "to choose is to die." Hirayama-san is torn between the contentment of a simple, ego-free, solitary life and the potential for greater happiness once it is shared with other human beings, or even transmitted (as seen with the two young girls he encounters throughout the story). A conviction that grips Hirayama-san when he rejects the idea that a shadow is not darker when the bodies of two beings juxtapose, because, despite his solitary instinct, he has understood: we are MORE together. A striking and poignant night scene modestly shot by Wenders. A scene that echoes the contrast between the first half of the film and the second. In the first part, Hirayama-san encounters numerous people, such as this "invisible" man (as they are called in Japan, those homeless individuals who wander the streets, ignored by everyone). He looks at him with tenderness, before his perception eventually changes towards the end as he understands that it could be his fate in a few yearsâ€¦

This internal conflict reflects a profoundly human sentiment: melancholy, a blend of resignation, towards unfulfilled destinies, and poetic contemplation of our existence. The film captures this powerlessness against time that defines our lives. This conclusion culminates in that very last frontal-shot sequence where Hirayama-san, uncertain whether to smile or cry, hesitates with which route to take in his car. Who knows which one is the right choice? Because only one thing remains certain: the sun will rise tomorrow and the day after. And by acknowledging it, he can control whether his day is going to be a perfect day or not.

This film will leave an everlasting impression on me because it's intertwining Japan, my country of adoption, and an existential crisis about destiny which deeply resonates with my doubt about having children, fearing the loss of "choice." 

The film ends with a title screen displaying the definition of komorebi.

Komorebi, the art displayed throughout the picture, consists in the shimmering light and shadows through tree leaves. This title sequence concludes with a note: Â« It only exists in the moment. Â» 

Like our very own lifespan on Earth.
